ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: Evaluating social movements from a critical and intersectional lens.
I learned so much about writing in general and about the history of social movements.
I learned more about the qualifications of a social movement, how different movements are connected, what movements matter most to me, and a lot about my writing process.
The growth and structure of social movements

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: Good amount of workload, interesting readings, Prof Kreiner did a great job leading our seminar discussions and prompting thought-provoking insights. Prof Kreiner is also INCREDIBLY understanding and flexible with deadlines, which we all really appreciated. However, there were some weaknesses in organization; there were a few instances where the readings and upcoming assignment submissions would not be uploaded and students were left in the dark wondering what we were supposed to do. The grading rubric was also unclear and students were graded harshly even though we did not spend much time in class talking about writing techniques.

Strengths: Tim is a good instructor and very personable. The opportunity to practice writing is essential.
Weaknesses: The readings were not discussed much in class so people stopped doing them.

I think the turnaround for papers might be a bit too quick. I think especially for the research paper, the time for research is really spring break which happens because of the way the semester is set up. Still, I think it isn't actually best to write cohesive works with well-thought-out, well-organized evidence. I also wish there were a few more office hours per paper offered or that the feedback for each draft was returned in a more timely manner. I also think there could be more room for student discussion? I don't know how to voice this thought completely, even though I loved the course I think sometimes our section didn't get to do too much roundtable talking about the readings or asking each other questions about thoughts we had.

Strengths: Great source material and content 
Weaknesses: Wish there were more engaging discussions in class

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes, if you are interested in social justice, politics, and history in relation to social movements. The workload is on the lower side and Prof Kreiner is flexible and generous with deadlines and extra credit, but it is definitely not an easy A.
Yes, for a first-year an excellent intro writing course!
Yes, its great for anyone regardless of major or interest
Yes. I think the content is amazing and there's definitely an emphasis on improving your writing skills while enjoying learning.
I would recommend this class to other students if they want to learn more about social movements and their structure. If you like history, you will like this class.

extras.title: ENGL 114 06 - What is a Social Movement?
